title: A Cap d’Antibes Villa That Accents the Vistas of the French Riviera
text:
Listing of the Day

Location: Cap d’Antibes, France

Price: €13.5 million (US$14.8 million)

One of about 1,000 villas perched on the Cap d’Antibes peninsula in the French Riviera, this residence is framed by the vistas that sprawl, on one side, to the Mediterranean Sea, and on the other, to the mountain ranges.

The views are what Martine Lemoine, listing agent with Christie’s International Real Estate affiliate Michaël Zingraf, marvels at most about the property, which is composed of a main abode and a guest house.

"Its geographic situation, views toward the attractive old town of Antibes and the snowy mountain tops during winter," are what make the estate special, she said.

Matching the grandeur of its surroundings, the home boasts a light beige neo-provincial hulk, rimmed with a dark brick-topped veranda.

More: Increasing Wealthy Population Buoying France’s Prime Real Estate Market

The residence also features what Ms. Lemoine calls a "triple reception," composed of an entertainment-centric living room, a media room and a dining room.

And, even if the two-story home, built in 2005, is striking, there is still space for further enhancements.

"The big interest of this property is that it has a building permit that would turn this house into a beautiful contemporary property," Ms. Lemoine said.

Stats

The residence sits on a plot of a little over an acre, making it quite a vast estate compared to other properties in Cap d’Antibes, Ms. Lemoine said.

The 4,300-square-foot main house has five bedrooms, three full bathrooms and as many half bathrooms. The guest house claims nearly 650 square feet, with two bedrooms and a bathroom.

More: What are the Property Taxes on a Cannes, France, Home?

Amenities

The basement of the main house has a gym and a sauna as well as a wine cellar.

Outside, anchoring the manicured grounds, a swimming pool splashes near the guest house, where its serenity yields to the cerulean Mediterranean waters.

Amid the abundant vegetation also lies a tennis court shared with the owners of two other properties.

There’s also a four-car garage.

Neighborhood Notes

Part of Antibes on Cote d’Azur, or the famed French Riviera, Cap d’Antibes rivets with its rugged, rocky edges and lush blanket of local flora. The villas that nestle on the peninsula often are owned by celebrities, who seek the privacy of the community away from the tourist bustle in Antibes.

"The neighborhood is cosmopolitan, quiet and residential," Ms. Lemoine said.

From Penta: Sotheby’s to Offer Francis Bacon’s ‘Pope’ on Behalf of Brooklyn Museum

As is expected from an enclave on the Mediterranean seashore, Cap d’Antibes lends itself to boating and yachting. On its east coast, among private docks, lies Port Salis, near a stretch of sandy beach—one of just a few along the otherwise craggy promontory. To the west, small, fishing boats dot Port de l’Olivette.

Although not devoid of its own historic and architectural sites, Cap d’Antibes borders what is one of Antibes’ primary attractions—the old town, with its tall buildings huddled along narrow, winding cobblestone streets.

Located between the cities of Cannes and Nice, Antibes, as well as its eponymous peninsula, are easily accessible by land, air and sea.

Listing agent: Martine Lemoine, Christie’s International Real Estate affiliate Michaël Zingraf
